description: Extracts printable ASCII and Unicode strings from binary files, memory dumps, or disk images. Essential for finding readable text in compiled executables, memory artifacts, or raw data.
forensicUse: Investigators use strings to find embedded URLs, IP addresses, file paths, error messages, hardcoded credentials, or encryption keys in malware samples and memory dumps.
simulatedOutput:
Found 142 printable strings in memory dump:
  → http://malicious-c2-server.com/payload
  → C:\Users\Admin\Documents\credentials.txt
  → API_KEY_3a8f9c2d1e7b4f6a
  → SELECT * FROM users WHERE admin=1
  → 42 additional strings matching pattern

description: Industry-standard memory forensics framework for analyzing RAM dumps. Extracts running processes, network connections, registry hives, command history, and malware artifacts from memory images.
forensicUse: Critical for incident response and malware analysis. Reveals processes hidden by rootkits, identifies code injection, recovers encryption keys, and reconstructs attacker activity from volatile memory.
simulatedOutput:
Memory Analysis Results:
  Processes detected: 47 active, 3 hidden
  → explorer.exe (PID 2847) - Legitimate
  → svchost.exe (PID 4921) - **SUSPICIOUS** (Code injection detected)
  → chrome.exe (PID 1234) - Legitimate
  Network Connections: 12 active, 2 to suspicious IPs
  → 192.168.1.105:443 → 203.0.113.87:4444 [MALICIOUS C2]

description: Open-source digital forensics platform with GUI for analyzing disk images, file systems, and mobile devices. Provides automated analysis, timeline generation, and comprehensive reporting.
usage: Launch GUI → Create Case → Add Data Source → Run Ingest
forensicUse: Law enforcement and corporate investigators use Autopsy for full-scale investigations. Automates artifact extraction, keyword searching, file carving, and timeline analysis for efficient case management.
simulatedOutput:
Case Analysis Complete:
  Case: 'drive_image.dd' | Size: 500GB
  Files analyzed: 1,247,583
  Deleted files recovered: 8,942
  Keyword hits: 234 matches for 'confidential'
  Timeline events: 15,847 across 30-day window
  Artifacts: 847 registry keys, 234 prefetch files, 92 browser history entries
  Evidence ready for export and reporting.

description: High-speed scanner that extracts structured information (emails, URLs, credit cards, phone numbers) from disk images without parsing file systems. Ignores file system structure for deep carving.
forensicUse: Ideal for finding PII, financial data, and communication artifacts in unallocated space, slack space, or damaged file systems. Processes terabytes of data quickly.
simulatedOutput:
Data Extraction Complete:
  Processed: 750GB in 38 minutes
  Email addresses: 2,847 unique (email.txt)
  URLs: 15,234 (url.txt)
  Credit cards: 93 valid PANs (ccn.txt)
  Phone numbers: 1,234 (telephone.txt)
  Histograms generated for frequency analysis
  Top domain: suspicious-marketplace.onion (247 references)

description: Collection of command-line tools (fls, icat, istat) for low-level file system forensics. Examines inodes, recovers deleted files, and analyzes disk structures on NTFS, FAT, ext4, and more.
forensicUse: Forensic examiners use Sleuth Kit for manual file system analysis, recovering deleted files by inode, examining metadata, and creating detailed file system timelines.
simulatedOutput:
File System Analysis:
  Partition table: MBR with 3 partitions
  File system: NTFS, 500GB capacity, 67% used
  Deleted files: 1,847 recoverable
  → Inode 128-144-3: 'confidential_memo.docx' (deleted 3 days ago)
  → Content NOT overwritten - full recovery possible
  MFT entry intact | Metadata preserved | File extracted successfully

description: Calculates cryptographic hashes (MD5, SHA-1, SHA-256, SHA-512) for files to ensure evidence integrity and verify file authenticity. Essential for chain of custody.
forensicUse: Every forensic investigation requires hash verification. Ensures evidence hasn't been tampered with, validates forensic images, and creates digital fingerprints for comparison.
simulatedOutput:
Hash Calculation Results:
  File: 'evidence_image.E01' | Size: 247GB
  MD5:    9f86d081884c7d659a2feaa0c55ad015
  SHA-1:  a3c2f1e8b7d9c4f6a8e1b2d3c5f7a9e2b4d6c8f1
  SHA-256: 2c26b46b68ffc68ff99b453c1d30413413422d706483bfa0f98a5e886266e7ae
  ✓ Hash verified against acquisition record
  Evidence integrity: CONFIRMED

description: Simulates file recovery from deleted partitions, formatted drives, or corrupted file systems. Scans for file signatures and reconstructs file headers for data restoration.
forensicUse: Critical for recovering evidence from intentionally deleted files, formatted drives, or damaged storage media. Uses file carving techniques to reassemble fragmented files.
simulatedOutput:
File Recovery Operation:
  Scanning deleted file entries...
  Found: 1,847 deleted files
  Recoverable: 1,623 (88% recovery rate)
  Successfully recovered:
    → evidence.log (23KB) - timestamps intact
    → deleted_email.pst (247MB) - 98% intact
    → financial_records.xlsx (1.2MB) - fully recovered
  Files saved to recovery directory with forensic metadata

description: Creates forensic timelines by aggregating file system timestamps (MACB: Modified, Accessed, Changed, Birth), registry entries, event logs, and application artifacts.
forensicUse: Timelines reconstruct attacker activity by correlating events across multiple sources. Reveals sequence of actions during breaches, establishes alibis, and identifies suspicious patterns.
simulatedOutput:
Forensic Timeline Generated:
  Time range: 2024-11-28 12:00:00 to 14:30:00
  Total events: 3,847
  Key events:
    12:15:47 - USB device connected (SanDisk 128GB)
    12:18:23 - File accessed: C:\Confidential\database.db
    12:21:05 - File copied to E:\ (USB drive)
    12:24:31 - Browser opened: private browsing mode
    12:47:18 - USB device disconnected
  Suspicious activity window: 12:15 - 12:47 (32 minutes)

description: Displays the current forensic investigator identity and system context. Shows active user, privileges, and forensic environment details.
forensicUse: Verifies forensic workstation identity and ensures analysis is performed under correct user context with appropriate privileges for evidence handling.
simulatedOutput:
Forensic Identity:
  User: root@forensec
  Role: Senior Digital Forensic Examiner
  Privileges: Administrator (Evidence Access Granted)
  Workstation: FORENSIC-LAB-07
  Active Case: #2024-11-28-001
  Certification: EnCE, GCFE, CHFI
  Evidence Integrity: Chain of custody active

description: Captures and analyzes network packets for investigating network-based attacks, data exfiltration, malware C2 communications, and protocol anomalies.
forensicUse: Network investigators use Wireshark to decrypt traffic, follow TCP streams, extract files from packets, identify malicious IPs, and reconstruct network-based attacks.
simulatedOutput:
Packet Analysis Results:
  Capture file: network_traffic.pcap | Duration: 4 hours
  Packets captured: 1,247,583
  Protocols: HTTP (34%), TLS (52%), DNS (8%), Other (6%)
  Suspicious findings:
    → 234 DNS queries to .onion domains (Tor)
    → Outbound connection to 203.0.113.87:4444 (C2 server)
    → HTTP POST with 14.7GB payload (data exfiltration)
  Files extracted: 47 executables, 234 documents

description: FTK Imager creates forensically sound disk images in E01 or DD format with built-in hash verification. Industry standard for evidence acquisition.
forensicUse: First step in any investigation. Creates bit-for-bit copies of storage media with cryptographic hashes to ensure evidence authenticity and allow non-destructive analysis.
simulatedOutput:
Disk Imaging Complete:
  Source: \\.\PhysicalDrive1 (500GB HDD)
  Destination: evidence_drive.E01
  Format: Expert Witness E01 (compressed)
  Compression: 35% (325GB final size)
  MD5: 5d41402abc4b2a76b9719d911017c592
  SHA-1: aaf4c61ddcc5e8a2dabede0f3b482cd9aea9434d
  Verification: PASS ✓
  Time elapsed: 2h 47m | Evidence preserved

description: Displays active network connections, listening ports, routing tables, and network interface statistics. Essential for live system analysis.
forensicUse: Identifies active malware connections, backdoors, and suspicious network activity on live systems. Shows which processes are communicating over the network.
simulatedOutput:
Active Network Connections:
  Protocol  Local Address      Foreign Address      State      PID
  TCP       192.168.1.105:443  203.0.113.87:4444   ESTABLISHED 4921 (svchost.exe) **SUSPICIOUS**
  TCP       192.168.1.105:80   10.0.0.5:51234      ESTABLISHED 1234 (chrome.exe)
  TCP       0.0.0.0:445        0.0.0.0:0           LISTENING   4
  UDP       0.0.0.0:53         *:*                             1824 (dns.exe)
  Warning: Connection to known C2 infrastructure detected!

description: Parses Windows Registry hives to extract user activity, USB devices, recently accessed files, network history, and malware persistence mechanisms.
forensicUse: Registry analysis reveals user behavior, connected devices, installed software, auto-start locations, and timeline artifacts critical for Windows investigations.
simulatedOutput:
Registry Analysis:
  Hive: NTUSER.DAT (User profile)
  Recent Documents: 234 files accessed
    → C:\Confidential\project_files\secret.docx (Last: 2024-11-28 12:15)
  USB History: 5 devices connected
    → SanDisk Extreme 128GB (Last: 2024-11-28 12:15:47)
  Auto-start Keys: 3 suspicious entries
    → HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\WindowsUpdate
      Value: C:\Users\Admin\AppData\malware.exe

description: Analyzes Windows Prefetch files to determine program execution history, including execution count and last run times. Proves program execution.
forensicUse: Prefetch analysis proves a specific executable ran on a system, when it ran, and how many times. Critical for establishing malware execution or user activity.
simulatedOutput:
Prefetch Analysis:
  File: MALWARE.EXE-A3D2F1C8.pf
  Program: C:\Users\Admin\AppData\Temp\malware.exe
  First executed: 2024-11-25 18:34:12
  Last executed: 2024-11-28 12:18:45
  Execution count: 47 times
  Files accessed: 234 DLLs and data files
  **Evidence: Malware repeatedly executed over 3-day period**

description: Parses Windows Event Logs (EVTX format) for security events, logons, process creation, service installation, and system changes.
forensicUse: Event logs document user logons, failed authentication attempts, privilege escalation, and administrative actions. Critical for incident response timelines.
simulatedOutput:
Event Log Analysis:
  Log: Security.evtx | Events: 15,847
  Event ID 4624 (Logon): 234 successful logons
    → User 'admin' logged on at 2024-11-28 02:34:17 (suspicious time)
  Event ID 4688 (Process Creation):
    → powershell.exe with encoded command at 02:35:42
  Event ID 7045 (Service Install):
    → 'WindowsUpdateService' created at 02:36:18 (persistence)
  **Timeline suggests automated attack at 2:34 AM**

description: Extracts EXIF metadata from images and videos including GPS coordinates, camera model, timestamps, and editing software. Proves authenticity and location.
forensicUse: EXIF data establishes when and where photos were taken, proves device ownership, detects photo manipulation, and provides geolocation evidence.
simulatedOutput:
EXIF Metadata Extraction:
  File: IMG_2847.jpg | Size: 4.2MB
  Camera: iPhone 13 Pro | Serial: DMQL2847KF
  Date Taken: 2024-11-28 14:32:18
  GPS Coordinates: 40.7589° N, 73.9851° W (New York, NY)
  Software: Adobe Photoshop 2024 (edited)
  **Location places suspect at crime scene during incident**
  **Editing timestamp shows photo modified after event**

description: Super timeline tool that extracts timestamps from file systems, registry, logs, and browser history. Creates comprehensive forensic timelines.
forensicUse: Plaso aggregates timestamps from hundreds of sources into unified timelines, revealing chronological sequence of events across entire systems.
simulatedOutput:
Super Timeline Generation:
  Processing: 500GB disk image
  Sources parsed: File system (NTFS), Registry, Event logs, Browser cache
  Total events: 2,847,583 timestamps
  Timeline range: 2024-01-01 to 2024-11-28
  Key activity clusters:
    → 2024-11-28 12:00-14:00: 847 events (data exfiltration window)
    → USB device usage, file access, network connections correlated
  Timeline database ready for analysis with psort.py

description: Pattern matching tool using YARA rules to identify malware signatures, malicious code patterns, and indicators of compromise in files or memory.
forensicUse: Malware hunters use YARA to scan systems for known malware families, detect variants, and identify suspicious code patterns based on behavioral signatures.
simulatedOutput:
YARA Scan Results:
  Rules: malware_signatures.yar (1,247 rules)
  Target: C:\Users\Admin\AppData\suspicious.exe

    ✓ Rule: Code_Injection_Technique [Medium]
    ✓ Rule: Network_C2_Communication [High]

description: Creates memory dump of running processes or full system RAM for forensic analysis. Captures volatile data before shutdown.
forensicUse: First responders acquire memory dumps to preserve volatile evidence like encryption keys, running malware, network connections, and passwords before system shutdown.
simulatedOutput:
Memory Acquisition:

description: File carving technique that recovers deleted files by identifying file signatures (headers/footers) in unallocated space without file system metadata.
forensicUse: Recovers files from formatted drives, deleted partitions, or fragmented storage by scanning raw data for file signatures. Bypasses file system damage.
simulatedOutput:
File Carving Operation:
  Scanning unallocated space: 150GB
  File signatures detected:
    → 847 JPEG images (jpg/jfif headers)
    → 234 PDF documents
    → 45 Microsoft Office files (docx/xlsx)
    → 12 Executable files (PE/MZ headers)
  Successfully carved: 1,023 files (87% intact)
  Extracted to: carved_files/
  Notable: deleted_evidence.pdf (fully recovered, 2.3MB)

description: Displays comprehensive list of all available forensic commands with descriptions and categories.
forensicUse: Reference guide for forensic investigators to discover available tools and understand their applications in digital investigations.

description: Clears terminal screen and command history for clean workspace.
forensicUse: Maintains organized terminal workspace during investigations by removing previous command output.

description: Provides in-depth forensic context and real-world investigation usage for specified command.
forensicUse: Educational tool that teaches investigators how commands are applied in actual criminal, corporate, and incident response investigations.

description: Presents forensic multiple-choice questions to test knowledge of digital investigation techniques and procedures.
forensicUse: Training tool for forensic students and investigators to validate understanding of forensic methodologies and best practices.

description: Loads random forensic case study from database showing real-world investigation scenarios with evidence, workflow, and outcomes.
forensicUse: Educational resource demonstrating complete investigation workflows from evidence collection to legal outcomes in various case types.

description: Command-line packet analyzer for capturing and analyzing network traffic in real-time or from capture files.
forensicUse: Live network traffic capture during incident response. Filters packets by IP, port, or protocol for targeted analysis of network-based attacks.

description: Extracts plaintext passwords, hashes, and Kerberos tickets from Windows memory. Used to detect credential theft attacks.
forensicUse: Forensic investigators analyze systems for evidence of Mimikatz usage indicating credential dumping attacks. Also used in authorized IR to identify compromised credentials.
simulatedOutput:
Credential Extraction Analysis:

    → User: dbadmin | NTLM: 8846f7eaee8fb117ad06bdd830b7586c
    → Kerberos tickets: 5 TGTs extracted

  Risk: Domain Administrator credentials compromised

description: Mounts forensic images in read-only mode for examination without modifying evidence. Supports E01, DD, and other forensic formats.
forensicUse: Read-only mounting ensures evidence integrity while allowing investigators to browse file systems, extract files, and analyze contents without modification.
